name: Mexican Orange
climate: Mexican Orange thrives in temperate climates that do not experience extreme temperatures.
This plant can handle mild winters, but harsh frost can damage or kill it.
It prefers regions with moderate humidity levels for optimal growth conditions.
Warm and mild climates with consistent temperatures all year are best.
sunlight: This plant prefers full sun to partial shade to achieve the best blooming results.
Mexican Orange can tolerate light shade, but full sun promotes dense and vibrant blooming.
When planted in partial shade, flowering may be reduced although foliage remains lush.
In hot climates, some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch and dehydration.
watering: Water the Mexican Orange regularly to keep the soil evenly moist, especially when young.
Established plants will require watering during prolonged dry periods, but avoid waterlogging.
It is best to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot.
During the growing season, consistent watering is necessary for flower production.
soil: This plant prefers well-draining soil enriched with organic matter for optimal growth.
Soil should be fertile and moist but with good drainage to prevent waterlogging issues.
Mexican Orange can grow in a range of soil types, including sandy and loamy soils.
Amending the soil with compost will improve its nutrient content and structure.
extra_care_tip: Prune the plant after flowering to maintain shape and encourage bushy growth.
Provide winter protection in areas prone to frost to prevent cold damage.
Mulching around the base can help retain moisture and keep roots cool in hot weather.
